title: 105_hr1736
content:
The "Teenage Pregnancy Reduction Act of 1997" is also known as the Act. It evaluates effective programs for preventing adolescent pregnancy. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate existing programs aimed at preventing adolescent pregnancy to determine their effectiveness, factors contributing to their success, and feasibility of replication in other locations. This evaluation may involve federal agencies and private organizations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate adolescent pregnancy prevention programs with input from various agencies and organizations with expertise in program evaluation. The evaluation design will consider programs in different regions and populations served. The Secretary will define measures of effectiveness for evaluating programs to reduce adolescent pregnancy, including factors specific to different demographics and gender. Funds for evaluation will be provided based on scientific peer review recommendations from experts in public and private entities. The evaluation of programs to reduce adolescent pregnancy will be completed by December 1, 2002, with a report submitted to Congress and the Secretary. Recommendations for future programs will be included in the report, which will be disseminated to various entities including prevention program administrators, organizations, and medical associations. Authorization of Appropriations: $3,500,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003 for public health, social work services, and school administrators. SEC. 3. ONE-TIME INCENTIVE GRANTS FOR EFFECTIVE PREVENTION PROGRAMS.

The Secretary may make a one-time grant to an effective prevention program to assist with operating expenses. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2004.

SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Prevention programs under this Act encompass various approaches for preventing adolescent pregnancy, including advocating abstinence, providing family planning services, promoting academic achievement, mentoring, job training, counseling, social events, or a combination of these methods. The Act defines a prevention program as a program for preventing adolescent pregnancy and the Secretary as the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
